comments.text: Do you know of anyone running a printed spinner on a gas engine?  Your success proves the material will handle the forces and can be balanced, but I worry about heat.  We are building a 134" Lancaster with 4 15cc engines and I have printed some scale spinners but have not had the chance to test whether they can take the stresses or not.
comments.author: pilotjunky

comments.text: The spinner would have to get up towards 200C (392F) for you to have to worry. But there are a lot of gas motors that run plastic spinners. I think it should be fine. If the engine was set up as a pusher, that might be an issue as the hot air from the cooling fins would flow over the prop. But in a typical tractor prop arrangement, the spinner will have lots of air flowing over it. I think you should be fine. But I might be able to convince some nitro guys at my flying field to use one of my spinners just to be sure.The think I might worry about is using a starter on the spinner.
comments.author: pilotjunky

comments.text: Thanks for the advice.  I am waiting for a new extruder from Makerbot... I wore mine out on the Replicator 2... when I get it set up I'm going to print on for testing on a gas engine.  Let me know if you have anyone test it on a glow engine.

title: Hypercube Evolution (HCE) Extruder Mount with TronXY/Anet Sensor

description.text:
*Note: I will be up to make some minor changes for people but please don't request mounts for other sensors that are not compatible with the TronXY XY-08N or the Anet Z Probe.

I had rigged my sensor to the side of the original extruder mount but wanted a better solution. I put this together in 3 varieties. One to have the sensor on the left, one to have the sensor on the right and another to have it on the left with the mount bracket only 2mm thick instead of 3mm to allow wiring to come out the front on that side. I have mine setup so the wires for the X endstop just come out of the front hole on the left side instead of running through the extruder mount to the right side.

To make your life easier, I highly recommend using the nut holder. If the nut is loose in the holder use super glue to hold it in place. If it is tight, heat it up and press it in.

Chip-E-lata - Give your Chip-E the meaty upgrades it deserves!

Ever wondered how much hardware you can fit onto a single Chip-E ? This entry to the Chip-E Remix Challenge aims to find out! Will it work? Who knows!

Features:

  • Walking
  • Two-wheeled rolling
  • Laser scanner
  • Water firing
  • Water turret

All of Chip-E's 3D printed parts have been modified to varying degrees, except for the thin top plate. The added 3D printed parts are aimed at being printer-friendly.
The Head part simply has 2 new holes for attaching the scanner mount block, which is a new part.
The midsection and base are modified include a circular right-hand extrusion for attaching the water turret, a rear extrusion for attaching the water reservoir, and a left-hand extrusion for attaching the pump's base unit.
The foot parts have been redesigned in order to be able to mount two motors pee foot. The positioning of the original foot servo is rotated 90 degrees to make space for the wheel servo. An additional joining bracket has been added to provide rigidity between the two servos.
Finally, a "smile" part has been added to give Chip-E a touch of personality!

The added electrical/mechanical components are:

  • x2 extra RobotGeek servos for wheeled mode
  • 2x Pololu 60x8 mm wheels
  • An Intel RealSense ZR300 depth camera
  • A RobotGeek Self-Priming Pump
  • The base unit of a Sparkfun Vacuum Pump
  • A Swiftech MCRES Micro Rev2 Reservoir for water storage
  • x2 6.35 mm (1/4") ID silicone tubing
  • x2 6.35 mm (1/4") ID tubing connectors
Update 05/07/2017

The main torso parts have been printed!

The next stage will be to get print the leg parts and water turret, and order all the electronics and hardware.

One small thing I missed was the additional mounting holes on the Head component for securing the top part of the water reservoir, but the two holes can easily be drilled out (STL file has been since updated to include these holes).

Chip-e-lata torso parts Front iso view Right-hand side, showing turret mounting point Rear, showing the reservoir holder Left-hand side, showing water pump mounting point

Behaviour

The planned behaviour of Chip-E-lata is:
1) Scan the room, find a target.
2) If target is close-by, walk over. Otherwise, convert to wheeled mode and drive over.
3) Extinguish fire or get your pet wet!

As Chip-E-lata is packed with hardware, it makes it suitable for anyone wanting to try out basic robot probramming, like simple walking gaits and controlling a pump, but also supports more advance features like two-wheeled balancing and 3D mapping.

Advanced control ideas

1) Get the robot to Balance on two-wheels like an inverted pendulum.
The idea is that the feet can 'jump' into wheeled mode and control can be activated in time to balance. The weight of the water reservoir may be issue, which could be overcome by using minimal minimal water, and/or moving the wheels further towards the rear.

2) Try out simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) algorithms using Intel's powerful new depth camera development kit.

3) Integrate the Chip-E-lata with ROS.
The robot is similar in hardware specs to the TurtleBot3. Your challenge: can you re-use code and features from the TurtleBot3? Can you outperform it?

As this is an experimental design, a few points would be worth considering before sending the files off to print:

  • Can the water pump utilise the base unit of the vaccum pump?
  • Do the bulky feet still allow space for normal walking (standard Chip-E walking gaits will probably need tweaking)?
  • Check reservoir hole positions (should be correct)
  • Find out correct scanner base hole distances/sizes (they were only a rough estimate by eye)
  • Consider speed/power capabilities of chosen wheel motors
  • Water turret pressure / water reach - Water cannon bore might need adjustment
  • Power requirements - Can a bigger battery fit in base?
  • Add a relay for the pump (should be able to squeeze into the main body)
  • Turret passive motion may require changing, consider adding ball bearings and manual position stepping/locking

AutoDesk Fusion 360 Project:
Chip-E-lata (Chip-E Remix Challenge)

Personal website:
Cognitive Dissonance

title: T-70 X-Wing x3 Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Latest Update: August 10, 2017. See Below for more

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible

So, here is my initial design for the T-70 X-Wing. This will hold 3 X-Wings and 8 Pilot Cards (TFA Core Set, T-70 X-Wing Expansion, Heroes of the Resistance). No room for the movement dials here.

There is one photo of a prior iteration, but with the Rebel Logo and "T-70 X-Wing" text painted in with white model paint. This would be a great opportunity for dual-extrusion (but I don't have dual-extrusion yet. If there are requests, I can probably put up another version ready for dual-extrusion, instead of a cut-out design.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well.

  • A-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397806
  • B-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477298
  • E-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2404410
  • K-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397829
  • Sabine's TIE Fighter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397957
  • T-65 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397667
  • T-70 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397764
  • YT-1300: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397827
  • YT-2400: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397816
  • Movement Dial Holder (7x): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397958

Yes, I will be posting Empire and Scum as I get to them.

UPDATE: July 1, 2017: Most models now have a v3.1 design, with the top of the cup lowered by 3mm, which will allow the "nubs" on the top of the Stanley Organizer to close better. Also, to accomodate this, I changed the Text and Logos to Raised instead of Sunken.

UPDATE: August 10, 2017: B-Wing Added! I haven't had a lot of time recently, so new designs are slow to come, but I am working on them. I am re-doing the Y-Wing design (it was printed in a gold and in one of the pics). Also, for those looking for color differences in materials, the X-Wing, A-Wing, and double B-Wing cups were printed with SainSmart Red PLA. For the Single B-Wing, K-Wing, E-Wing, Attack Shuttle, YT-1300, YT-2400 and Sabine's TIE Fighter, I used the GP3D Red PLA. I must say that I much prefer the color and finish of the GP3D Red over the SainSmart Red.

UPDATE: February 6, 2018: Life has kept me away from designing, so I haven't been able to work on any new designs in a while. I still intend to finish out the Rebel fleet, and then move on to the Imperials and Scum, but time will tell. In the interim, check out 3D_Pressure's Designs. While 3D_Pressure and I differ on a few design ideas, he has continued on in the spirit of my designs, and I really like some of his creative ideas.

Note #2: I know the YT-2400 and YT-1300 designs are a little tight sometimes. Next time I do a set of revisions, I will open up the hollow for both ships a little bit.

Maker Select v2.1

Yes

20% (10% is fine too)

title: Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II JSF

description.text:
This is the Lockheed Martin Joint Strike Fighter. I tried to put as many details in the top as possible. The belly has some details, but not everything since it mostly isn't visible on the stand.

This is the best way I could slice it to get the strength in the wings and tails, but will require a small amount of support behind the engine I imagine. If you have any issues, let me know and I'll rectify the problems as soon as I can.

If you enjoy the model and would be so kind to support me monatarily for my work please consider supporting here: https://www.patreon.com/oranhunter

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_N5uoVgAZ3M" ></iframe>
Volume warning, starts with loud-ish music.  Also, a little dizzying for those sensitive to quick movement.

comments.text: I thought you'd like to know, your model is currently sitting on a desk at the Ft. Worth plant where the F-35 is produced. I'd take a picture, but I'm not allowed to ;-). You did a good job!

comments.text: That's incredible! Thanks for letting me know!
comments.author: Sittinduck21

comments.text: How does the plane attach to the stand? do you just glue the damn thing or is there supposed to be a hole. I printed the entire plane on 75% scale and there isn't a notch for the plane to go onto the stand.
comments.author: COND

comments.text: Hmmm. That's strange. Perhaps you're slicing software filled in the hole for the stand peg?

comments.text: Ah! I Gotcha. Yeah the unsliced versions that I post are just the completed sculpt. The assumption is that you're using it as a toy for a child(as in the case when I print aircraft for my kids) or you're planning to slice the clean version yourself.

comments.text: i like your models alot, maybe posting a non split version for very small scales would be cool...so figuring out the scale could be easier... at least for me knowing whats the scale its important so when printing it, it can sit next to other figures on a realistic(?) proportional (?) scale...I will figure it out.. you have done the hardest part.....great skills for 2 years expierience!  thanks again for sharing!

comments.text: I appreciate your feedback, I'm glad when people like my models. Everything about the model is proportional, but its not a specific scale. Blender(the software I work with) makes it a challenge to export models with any really great accuracy without going through some pretty ridiculous loops. But I think I understand what you're saying, if you had a version of it that you could easily determine the wingspan(for example) is 3.5 inches on your print bed, it would be exactly 1:120?

comments.text: please share!  that would be great! i was trying to scale it to 1/144 and 1/200 with out putting it back together, very true i was using the wingspan to do the measures.......

comments.text: 1/144 would be scaling the whole thing down to 42%. 30.3% would be 1/200. I'll upload the unsliced as well.

title: Jambiya Knive - Battlefield 1 (Lawrence of Arabia dagger)

description.text:
A printable version of Jambiya Dagger of T.E. Lawrence, English officer in the first World War also known as Laurence Of Arabia.
Its based on the design of the videogame Battlefield one, and the work of the team of Men at Arms forging a real replica.( https://youtu.be/c8AsONB6F4s )

Doesn't Matter

20

Notes:

Printed in abs. Splited the blade in two halves using rafts to prevent warping.
Handle must be printed in two parts cutting it horizontally, If you print it vertically yo will lose the details of the pomel top bezels.
In this moment its in painting progres. Then i will emboss a fake stones in the bezels.
Enjoy.

Need to enlarge the jewel bezels due the cristals i found were too biz and bezels are irregular.
I did it with a Dremel tool.
Now Its being primed and then I doubt between a gold spray paint or use gold leaf.
i wil post the resulting images.

author: fritztoch

description.text: A 3D scan of a cool frog mask made with 123D Catch and attached to a base to make it printable.

At a small size (approximately a 1 inch base) this model takes about 50 mins to print. At the large default size (about 3 inch base) it takes about 5 hours. The large image shown here was printed between those two and took 2.5 hours.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:340321

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=340321

Using the following options:

BlockWidth = 2
BlockLength = 10
Name = Francesca

After breaking countless 1104 motors during crashes, I decided to design these. Over the past year, these have been the saviors of my motors and my bank account! Stop buying motors in bulk and instead let these 11XX Motor Guards take the abuse! They are incredibly strong and have proven highly effective during testing.

Don't own a 3D printer? No problem! Get the PLA versions of these motor guards on eBay.

For installation information, skip to 23:30 on my Aurora 100 Review and Mod video.

Note: They are compatible with most 1103, 1104, 1105, and 1106 motors though optimized for 1104. If you use 1103 motors, you may need to sand down the top a bit.

Updates:

9/17/2017: Added V2. .5mm thicker bottom, extra strength chamfer, and added a hole in the center to access the C/E clip.

9/17/2017: Added V3 which simply has a chamfer on the inner edge to prevent the guard from getting caught in smaller motor bells in the event that they break.

10/14/17: Added V3 TPU which has an increased wall thickness and smaller diameter screw holes to prevent M2 bolts with small heads from sinking into the guard and causing it to fall off. I really like the TPU motor guards and highly suggest that you give them a try.

10/14/17: Added V1 NinjaFlex TPU 1106 edition motor guards. These are specifically designed to be printed in NinjaFlex TPU and be used for 1106 motors. NinjaFlex is the most flexible TPU currently on the market making it ideal for soft mounting motors. By pairing these NinjaFlex motor guards with soft mounting pads, you get silky smooth soft-mounted flight.

10/14/17: Added 11XX soft mounting pads. These simply get installed under your motor and help ensure that motor vibrations don't get transferred to the rest of your quad. With my limited testing, these give you silky smooth flight. For best results, print in NinjaFlex TPU and pair with TPU motor guards.

10/30/17: Added specialized NinjaFlex TPU motor guards for 1102, 1103, 1104, and 1105 motors. (earlier update included the TPU motor guards for 1106.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Use your default settings

Infill:

100%

Onshape

I designed this on Onshape. If you have a similarly sized motor, you can make a copy of my document and easily change the dimensions for your custom needs. Just look in the folder "Universal Mods".

Available on eBay

If you don't own a 3D printer, these 1104 Motor Guards are available on eBay.

title: A-Wing x3 Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Latest Update: August 10, 2017. See Below for more

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible

So, here is my initial design for the A-Wing. This will hold 3 A-Wings and 8 Pilot Cards (A-Wing Expansion, Rebel Aces, 1 more). Movement Dials are included.

A "A-Wing Small" version is also included for 2x A-Wings and 4 pilot cards, but no movement dials.

The Rebel Logo and "A-Wing" text can painted in with white model paint. This would be a great opportunity for dual-extrusion (but I don't have dual-extrusion yet. If there are requests, I can probably put up another version ready for dual-extrusion, instead of a cut-out design.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well.

  • A-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397806
  • B-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477298
  • E-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2404410
  • K-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397829
  • Sabine's TIE Fighter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397957
  • T-65 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397667
  • T-70 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397764
  • YT-1300: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397827
  • YT-2400: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397816
  • Movement Dial Holder (7x): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397958

Yes, I will be posting Empire and Scum as I get to them.

UPDATE: July 1, 2017: Most models now have a v3.1 design, with the top of the cup lowered by 3mm, which will allow the "nubs" on the top of the Stanley Organizer to close better. Also, to accomodate this, I changed the Text and Logos to Raised instead of Sunken.

UPDATE: August 10, 2017: B-Wing Added! I haven't had a lot of time recently, so new designs are slow to come, but I am working on them. I am re-doing the Y-Wing design (it was printed in a gold and in one of the pics). Also, for those looking for color differences in materials, the X-Wing, A-Wing, and double B-Wing cups were printed with SainSmart Red PLA. For the Single B-Wing, K-Wing, E-Wing, Attack Shuttle, YT-1300, YT-2400 and Sabine's TIE Fighter, I used the GP3D Red PLA. I must say that I much prefer the color and finish of the GP3D Red over the SainSmart Red.

UPDATE: February 6, 2018: Life has kept me away from designing, so I haven't been able to work on any new designs in a while. I still intend to finish out the Rebel fleet, and then move on to the Imperials and Scum, but time will tell. In the interim, check out 3D_Pressure's Designs. While 3D_Pressure and I differ on a few design ideas, he has continued on in the spirit of my designs, and I really like some of his creative ideas.

Note #2: I know the YT-2400 and YT-1300 designs are a little tight sometimes. Next time I do a set of revisions, I will open up the hollow for both ships a little bit.

Printer:

Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.16 first layer

Infill:

20% (10% is fine too)

Notes:

Printed in PLA @ 200, Bed @ 65
40mm/sec, Retraction Enabled

NOTE: The normal design includes "feet" on the cup, so supports are required. If you use the no-feet version, no supports are required. I have not tried printing upside down.
Paint or white crayon into the Rebel Logo & "A-Wing" text. Insert your pilot cards, movement dials and A-Wings, then place inside your Stanley Organizer.
Designed in OnShape (Files are available on OnShape)

comments.text: Thanks for this! I had tried printing the small version that fits 2 ships, but the cutouts won't fit anything.  After printing the 3 ship version, I noticed that they're shaped differently.  I'm using the 3 ship version for now, but is there any chance you might go back someday and fix the 2 ship one?

comments.text: How hard are these to take out of the organizer when it is full?  It doesn't look like there's too much room for your fingers.
comments.author: Ryan00101010

comments.text: The design is a little tight, and typically, I just take the cup out of the organizer and tip it over to get the ships out. A remix to add some thumb-area to grab the ships by might be a worthwhile mod. With most of my designs, the ship is a little loose, intentionally, so it slides out easily. The pilot cards can get a little tight sometimes, so I have started to add a little more space for them to be free. The Dials usually can be pulled out easily, but are just tight enough to not fall out on their own.

title: Runcam Swift Micro mount for Shendrones Shrieker

description.text: This lets you easily mount a Runcam Swift Micro to a Shendrones Shrieker at a fixed 30 degrees. There are 3 sizes for 25mm, 30mm, and 35mm standoffs as well as 1 45 deg mount for 25mm standoffs. Pictures shown are with the 25mm 30 deg version.

comments.text: I downloaded the 25 degree versions and printed them.  First print didn't fit (probably because I'm a 3D printing noob) so I printed again 110% scale and they fit.  After flying awhile I determined I wanted to try lowering the angle.  Since these didn't have shallower angles available I remixed it myself for 15 degrees.  However, in doing so I found that the original 25 degree files are actually 30 degrees.  I easily may have miss-measured, but I checked a couple of times and they seem to be 30 degrees.  Can anyone confirm the 30 degree on the 25 degree ones?
comments.author: coolrazor

comments.text: Oh and as far as it fitting the standoffs, it's meant to be printed in TPU, and it's meant to be tight. I print mine at 100% and they fit great. If you use a harder material though you may have to upscale or ream the hole out some.
comments.author: coolrazor

comments.text: Ok, that makes a lot more sense.  I printed in PLA and it just wouldn't give.  I feel silly misreading the 25 to mean degrees not milometers for the height, lol.
comments.author: Quad_Logic

comments.text: Hey no worries! Hope it works out for you.
comments.author: coolrazor

comments.text: All of these mounts are 30 degrees on the camera angle. The different versions are for 25mm, 30mm, or 35mm standoffs. If you are able to change the design yourself to 25 degrees you'll probably also need to bring the mounting position down about 1mm because at 30 degrees the camera is already almost touching the top plate.
comments.author: coolrazor

title: YT-2400 Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Latest Update: August 10, 2017. See Below for more

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible

So, here is my initial design for the YT-2400. This will hold the YT-2400 and the movement dial. Every attempt to include the pilot card for a Medium Base ship has ended with an unprintable design, or would require way to many supports and cleanup.

description.text:
A Lego café racer built on the recent minifigure-scale chassis, as seen in set 60084. Some inspiration was drawn from the Moto Morini Corsaro 1200 and the 2006-model Triumph Speed Triple.

The .lxf file contains three variants:

  • the ordinary street variant, clad in Racing Red;
  • a Scorched Yellow reskin with a steel frame;
  • and a GP racer, modified similarly to bikes in Tourist Trophy (PS2, 2006).

FICTIONAL STATS

  • Engine Type: 90° V2, longitudinally mounted
  • Engine Displacement: 820 cc
  • Max. Power (Street): 102 bkW @ 9600 rpm
  • Max. Power (GP): 114 bkW @ 10200 rpm
  • Frame Type: Semi-monocoque
  • Dry Weight (Street): 146 kg
  • Dry Weight (GP): 144 kg
  • Transmission: 8-speed manual

title: YT-1300 Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Latest Update: August 10, 2017. See Below for more

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible

So, here is my initial design for the YT-1300 a.k.a. "Millennium Falcon". This will hold the YT-1300 and the movement dial. Every attempt to include the pilot card for a Medium Base ship has ended with an unprintable design, or would require way to many supports and cleanup.

NOTE 1: This will work for the original "Millennium Falcon" from the YT-1300 Expansion or for the "Heroes of the Rebellion" version.

NOTE 2: This is a non-standard size "cup", equal to a large & 2 smalls, so it fits best in the side next to the handle in the Stanley Organizer.

NOTE 3: My print was a bit too tight, and the Falcon doesn't slide all the way down, so it is at an angle. I have modified the dimensions so future prints should slide down. Please let me know if you run into any issues

The Rebel Logo and "YT-1300" text can painted in with white model paint. This would be a great opportunity for dual-extrusion (but I don't have dual-extrusion yet. If there are requests, I can probably put up another version ready for dual-extrusion, instead of a cut-out design.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well.

UPDATE: July 1, 2017: Most models now have a v3.1 design, with the top of the cup lowered by 3mm, which will allow the "nubs" on the top of the Stanley Organizer to close better. Also, to accomodate this, I changed the Text and Logos to Raised instead of Sunken.

UPDATE: August 10, 2017: B-Wing Added! I haven't had a lot of time recently, so new designs are slow to come, but I am working on them. I am re-doing the Y-Wing design (it was printed in a gold and in one of the pics). Also, for those looking for color differences in materials, the X-Wing, A-Wing, and double B-Wing cups were printed with SainSmart Red PLA. For the Single B-Wing, K-Wing, E-Wing, Attack Shuttle, YT-1300, YT-2400 and Sabine's TIE Fighter, I used the GP3D Red PLA. I must say that I much prefer the color and finish of the GP3D Red over the SainSmart Red.

UPDATE: February 6, 2018: Life has kept me away from designing, so I haven't been able to work on any new designs in a while. I still intend to finish out the Rebel fleet, and then move on to the Imperials and Scum, but time will tell. In the interim, check out 3D_Pressure's Designs. While 3D_Pressure and I differ on a few design ideas, he has continued on in the spirit of my designs, and I really like some of his creative ideas.

Note #2: I know the YT-2400 and YT-1300 designs are a little tight sometimes. Next time I do a set of revisions, I will open up the hollow for both ships a little bit.

description.text:
I posted this up on reddit and few people asked for the STLs and more info on it.

From the 3D printing side of things, this uses a cheap 5" LCD from ebay with HDMI inputs and a Raspberry PI with a 3.5" backpack - the part list below is just for the screen setup.

Parts list is:

20 x 5mm M3 Bolts
2 x 20mm M3 Bolts
2 x M3 nuts
1 x Raspberry Pi (I used a 2, but any version would work)
1 x WiFi Dongle (https://goo.gl/YLTriL)
1 x 3.5" LCD Screen, like this (https://goo.gl/fKM6Bf) - note that I pulled the touch screen off
1 x 5" LCD Screen like this (https://goo.gl/m6Vxc3) - note that I pulled the touch screen off
2 x Micro USB connectors and wire for power
1 x 90 Degree HDMI Connector to minimise footprint needed (https://goo.gl/tnCoaC)

All the parts are fairly straight forward to print, you will probably need to adjust the supports for the raspberry pi and LCD, I printed these to suit the units I have, but I suspect with the cheaper LCDs there will be some differences. That is why you will note there is no mounting holes for the supports - I positioned those then drilled them manually.

I had a lot of people ask about the way I had everything configured, so here is a more detailed information. Note that I won't do my own tutorials or information on stuff that already has a heap of information out there (like setting up Apache etc...), but I'll make note of it.

Overall, the Raspberry Pi Webserver runs a SQL database that collects the stats, a bash script running on the router sends stats to the SQL Database. We can then present and read the data from there.

Please refer to the Logical Diagram in the files for reference to the below steps.

1) Sophos UTM

I use Sophos UTM as my home router, its a basic PC with the Sophos image running on it, its an awesome router/firewall setup, very easy to use and very flexible.

More information is available here: https://www.sophos.com/en/products/free-tools/sophos-utm-home-edition.aspx

I won't go into detail into how to set it up as there are plenty of guides out there, but for the following information you will need it setup and working with SSH for loginuser enabled and know the root password. You will also need to save an SSH connection to the destination server - plenty of information around on that.

The Raspberry WebServer runs an SQLLite Database to record the stats for the webserver. I had used flat files originally, but I had issues with file locking when trying to write and read the data, so I switched to a basic SQL database setup.

a) Login to the UTM Box via SSH, you should be at /home/login/, but just make sure.
b) Create a BASH script using nano and copy/paste the content from Serverstats_bash in the files section. Update [email protected] to the username and IP address of the Raspberry Pi in step 2 below. Save and exit, making sure the file name is serverstats
c) run Sudo crontab -e
d) Copy/paste the line from crontab in the file section.
e) Once step 2 below is complete, this should start sending stats to the DB

2) Raspberry Pi Webserver

This is a headless Raspberry Pi Server running Apache, PHP and SQLLite. Guides are available here:
Apache2/PHP: https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/remote-access/web-server/apache.md
SQLLite: http://raspberrywebserver.com/sql-databases/set-up-an-sqlite-database-on-a-raspberry-pi.html

I have a number of websites setup as VHosts, you can configure it however you want. The important bit is that the SQL Database is called serverstats.bd and sits in the same folder as the website and php files.

Look at the ZIP file called WebServer for all the respective files. The PHP file pulls the data from the SQL DB and presents it to the browser.

If all goes to plan, you should see stats and the traffic lights should also change colours depending on the load. Note that this is configured with my crappy internet speed, you will need to edit the traffic light conditions to trigger when you want them to. If you are still following at this point, it should be pretty easy to work out :)

3) Local Router LCD

So my router has a local 1602 LCD, power by an Arduino with an Ethernet shield to present the local stats on the router, Arduino code is attached, I won't go into to much detail with this one, but it needs physical RGB LEDs to show the load, and an I2C 1602 LCD. Code is commented so should be easy to follow and edit.

File is UTMDisplayV5.ino

4) Raspberry Pi Powered LCD Screen

At this point, you should be able to browse to the Raspberry Webserver above and see the stats presented, so the next step is to setup a Raspberry Pi with an LCD back pack that can see the website.

For my LCD, I needed to use the following Raspbian image: http://osoyoo.com/2016/09/13/install-raspberry-pi-3-5-touch-screen-driver-for-raspbian-jessie/

I had issues running Kiosk mode properly, so I'm using Firefox for Raspbian, autostarting that with the right website URL and then using a full screen plugin for firefox to accomplish the same thing.

I then used Unclutter to hide the mouse cursor - https://ubuntu-tutorials.com/2008/07/07/auto-hide-your-mouse-pointer-when-idle-with-unclutter/

Job done :)

5) 3D Printed casing - instructions at the very top :)

6) This is the 5" LCD that is actually a 3rd Monitor (I run dual screen) from my PC. This is very straight forward, needs 5V power (Like the raspberry pi), and an HDMI feed from the PC.

I then use Aida64 to setup something to display on it - https://www.aida64.com/

I know I have covered the setup very quickly and probably missed out a few things, but the point of this guide was to demonstrate the theory and articulate what was possible, I'm not an expert in these sort of technologies, just a lot of googling to make it work, but it works well - happy to discuss in comments.

EDIT: A few people wanted to edit the model itself, so I have shared out the Fusion Designs via these links:

This is a set of light brackets for the Vaterra Twin Hammers, just bolt them on and go.
the mounts are designed for the Vaterra Glamis Fear Light Pods, but you could also use any light bar or pods. this setup just works great for some nice brackets. https://www.horizonhobby.com/light-set-with-buckets%3A-glf-vtr340003

i also included some nice pop-in light buckets.

the roof mount uses 3 2.5mm machine screws to fasten to the front of the roof pannel.
the front bracket uses 2 2.5mm machine screws to connect to the roll cage.

I used PLA at 100 microns to print the parts and as you can see in the pictures the brackets held up great to some heavy bashing.

the rear bumper (or if you want to use the included tail light inserts you can, i like the 1 piece better myself) uses the red LED harness from the Traxxas Summit and the stock VTH hardware
https://www.rcplanet.com/Traxxas_LED_Lights_Rear_Harness_Summit_p/tra5688.htm?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIl-Xk4v7P1AIVQ2V-Ch1zhwguEAQYAyABEgK4BPD_BwE

if you use the inserts they just slot load into the rear bumper no sanding required.

hope you enjoy the parts and please post your makes i want to see them.

I own an older RV and got tired of running the cable hookup through the window at campgrounds. You will need to drill a hole in the exterior of your RV, so use plenty of Caulk behind the cover before you attach it. I believe the screw holes should fit #8 pan head screws(I haven't installed it yet) and reinforced the areas behind the screw heads. One run to my local cable company dumpster got me the double ended coax connector and rubber boot that you see in the picture, of course they are also available where coax is sold. I just prefer to re-purpose. I sized the center hole so that you have to force the connector into the hole creating your own threads.You can also widen the hole but you run the risk of not having a thin enough nut to fasten it on the rear and still connect the interior connection.

The fogger has an optimal distance below the water that it works, this floating platform keeps it at that level no matter what the water level is at.

Fogponics is an advanced form of aeroponics which uses water in a vaporised form to transfer nutrients and oxygen to enclosed suspended plant roots. Using the same general idea behind aeroponics, fogponics uses a 5–30 µm mist within the rooting chamber and as use for a foliar feeding mechanism. Plants best absorb particles from the 1–25 µm range, the smaller particulate size means faster absorption.[citation needed] The added benefit of using fogponic's over traditional hydroponics systems is that the plants require less energy in root growth and mass, and are able to still sustain a large plant.

You can reach me directly on my email [email protected] Our Polycom video link at Fab Lab Stoughton USA is currently under repair - it should be fixed soon. comments.author: mannix1257

comments.text:
Hello mannix1257,
I'm very glad to hear that you have addressed the problem. I wish you will enjoy making.
As to 4 wing ornithopters, there are several variations from small rubber-powered models to large RC birds. Most of them use carbon rods and carbon tubes for their construction. I usually order these carbon materials via internet from hobby suppliers.
In order to share the designs with someone, I have recently completed the 3D-CAD data of the two 4 winged ornis, one is rubber-powered and the other is RC. I'm now working on the instructions for them and hopefully I can publish them in a few days. I will include the source for materials necessary to construction.
I am a member of Fablab Kitakagaya(Osaka, Japan). It would be highly appreciated that we can share our experiences and ideas.
Thank you.

title: Pipe Cutting Jig attached to a 2x4

description.text:
I recently needed to cut 12 - 1/2" EMT (Electrical Metal Tubing) all the same lengths, so I came up with this simple holding bracket screwed to a 2"x4". I am using a Rigid 101 Tubing cutter http://www.homedepot.com/p/RIDGID-101-Tubing-Cutter-40617/100075014 . I made the bracket so it was a snug fit against the cutter. I printed 3 brackets for the size pipe I was using & a EMT_Cut_Jig_8mmSpacer_Rev4.stl. I only needed the third bracket when the pipe was really long.

You need 1 - 2"x4" a little longer than the pipe you are going to cut. The 2nd 2"x4" can be relatively short. I also used a small 1"x2" screwed to the end of the 2x4 so the pipe would butt up against it as shown in the photos. As the photos show, I marked the 2x4 where I wanted the cut to be & used the 8mm spacer to get the location of the bracket & used the wood screws I had on hand to mount the bracket. Once the 2 brackets are mounted, it is then very simple to attach the cutter tight in place & remove it from the brackets to cut it. When removing the pipe to cut, it is better to pull it away from the end before pulling it out so it will not scar up the 1x2 board at the end.

I included a customizable openscad file so you can make a bracket for most any diameter pipe. You could also use this for other pipe cutters, you will just need to measure it a little differently. There is a dimensioned image that shows the variables you might want to change in the openscad file. I made a STL file for the 3 main MPCNC style machines.

comments.text:

author: GeoDave

description.text: At 19,341 ft Mt. Kilimanjaro is the highest mountain in the Africa. This is part of my series of "collectible mountains". All the models in this series are rendered at 1:100000. The model represents an area 10km x 10km. The bottom of the model sits at sea level so the different mountains can be accurately compared. Have you even wondered just how much bigger Everest is than Mt Shasta? Now you can hold them both in your hands and compare. Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

title: Skate Riser Lights
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are risers with space inside to put LEDs, a battery, charging board, and switch that can be screwed in as a riser between the trucks and the board (albeit a big one). Plus side is the riser will be protected by the base of the trucks so there should be little chance of it getting banged up or destroyed in a head on collision with a curb or the like.

Used a TP4056 for recharging a 350mAh battery that fits in the case and a small slide switch for turning power on and off, will post the PCB design once it has been completed.

V2 is only .5" tall so closer to a "regular" riser size, made some of these using silicone molds for more rigidity but should work fine if printed from ABS or Nylon (would suggest pretty high infill 50% or more if you plan to just use the 3D printed versions, tried with PLA but it breaks down eventually and cracks).

title: Sabine's TIE Fighter Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Latest Update: August 10, 2017. See Below for more

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible

So, here is my initial design for Sabine's TIE Fighter (a.k.a. Rebel TIE Fighter). No room for the movement dial or pilot cards here.

The Rebel Logo and "Sabine's TIE Fighter" text can painted in with white model paint. This would be a great opportunity for dual-extrusion (but I don't have dual-extrusion yet. If there are requests, I can probably put up another version ready for dual-extrusion, instead of a cut-out design.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well.

  • A-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397806
  • B-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477298
  • E-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2404410
  • K-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397829
  • Sabine's TIE Fighter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397957
  • T-65 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397667
  • T-70 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397764
  • YT-1300: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397827
  • YT-2400: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397816
  • Movement Dial Holder (7x): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397958

Yes, I will be posting Empire and Scum as I get to them.

UPDATE: July 1, 2017: Most models now have a v3.1 design, with the top of the cup lowered by 3mm, which will allow the "nubs" on the top of the Stanley Organizer to close better. Also, to accomodate this, I changed the Text and Logos to Raised instead of Sunken.

UPDATE: August 10, 2017: B-Wing Added! I haven't had a lot of time recently, so new designs are slow to come, but I am working on them. I am re-doing the Y-Wing design (it was printed in a gold and in one of the pics). Also, for those looking for color differences in materials, the X-Wing, A-Wing, and double B-Wing cups were printed with SainSmart Red PLA. For the Single B-Wing, K-Wing, E-Wing, Attack Shuttle, YT-1300, YT-2400 and Sabine's TIE Fighter, I used the GP3D Red PLA. I must say that I much prefer the color and finish of the GP3D Red over the SainSmart Red.

UPDATE: February 6, 2018: Life has kept me away from designing, so I haven't been able to work on any new designs in a while. I still intend to finish out the Rebel fleet, and then move on to the Imperials and Scum, but time will tell. In the interim, check out 3D_Pressure's Designs. While 3D_Pressure and I differ on a few design ideas, he has continued on in the spirit of my designs, and I really like some of his creative ideas.

Note #2: I know the YT-2400 and YT-1300 designs are a little tight sometimes. Next time I do a set of revisions, I will open up the hollow for both ships a little bit.

Printer:

Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.16 first layer

Infill:

20% (10% is fine too)

Notes:

Printed in PLA @ 200, Bed @ 65
40mm/sec, Retraction Enabled

NOTE: The normal design includes "feet" on the cup, so supports are required. If you use the no-feet version, no supports are required. I have not tried printing upside down.
Paint or white crayon into the Rebel Logo & "Sabine's TIE Fighter" text. Insert TIE Fighter, then place inside your Stanley Organizer.
Designed in OnShape (Files are available on OnShape)

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. Sadly, the Stanley "Small Cup" leaves no room for the Movement Dial, and some other designs would have to give up too much space. There are 3 versions (so far). A Plain One (just "X-Wing Miniatures" text), one for 6x TIE Fighter & 1 TIE Striker (Core Set, TFA Core Set, TIE Fighter Expansion, Gozani Cruiser), and one for 3x T-65 X-Wing (Core Set, X-Wing Expansion, Rebel Transport) & 3x T-70 X-Wing (TFA Core Set, T-70 X-Wing Expansion, Heroes of the Resistance) and 1x Y-Wing (Y-Wing Expansion). The reason for the lone Y-Wing is that I have 2x Scum & Villany sets, so it was easier to design a 3x Y-Wing holder for Scum. I can probably change the text for folks upon request, or go to OnShape and you can modify it yourself.

remixed_from.title: Wanhao i3 Plus Bearing Spool Holder

title: Wanhao i3 Plus Bearing Spool Holder with increased clearance
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of jpotegal's spool holder.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2249488

Main differences are:
1) The spool holder has been raised around 25mm to provide more clearance for large spools. I needed this to avoid contact with my enclosure.
2) It's been narrowed to fit spools with diameters as low as 32mm, such as those that come with Cocoon Create printers.
3) The clearances on each side between bearing and spool holder have been shrunk to 0.5mm.
4) A small flange has been placed on each side of the roller to make sure the spool stays centred and doesn't rub on the main frame.
5) The roller has been moved closer to the spool holder support (it now sits within the vertical piece of frame that connects the main bearing arm to the threaded section.

There are 71mm and 85mm versions.
Update 23/6/17: and now a 100mm version. I'd use lots of infill and shells for that. :D

Update 25/08/17
Added a 608 bushing for people who don't have access/want to use ball bearings.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 for nut and frame, 0.2 for roller

Infill:

Yes. It's a structural piece

Notes:

I printed both spool frame and roller in the vertical position. The frame was printed with the threaded end down.

comments.text: With PLA, I suggest printing the threaded part of the frame at 0.1mm or lower layer height, with >2 shells, and >75% infill for strength. Then either restarting the print for the rest of the frame with 0.2mm layer height and lower infill %, or if you can't do restarts, gluing the rest of the frame to the threaded part. I did my frame at 0.1mm layer height with 2 shells and 20% infill and ended up having to coat my threads in a thin shell of superglue to keep them from splitting when I tighten down the nut. Note: The threads are not the same as the original, so you'll have to print the nut.

comments.text: Maybe over-extrusion. I've got mine set to extrude at 100% and a 2.4mm wall ends up very close to 2.4mm. The other thing is, if it's not fitting the end that was on the build surface, then it could be that your first layer or two is a bit fat.

I'd try backing off your extrusion rate a touch, and if that doesn't work, you can probably scale the part up in a slicer by a percent or two. The axle as a bump at each end to keep the spool on the axle, so there's a bit of tolerance to play with.

title: 3D PRINT READY!! Weiss Schnee from RWBY

description.text:
This print is ready to go and does not need any more fixing to be printed!

3D Print other RWBY models here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2357481 Ruby Rose
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397963 Weiss Schnee
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2447958 Blake Belladonna
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2471634 Yang Xiao Long
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504153 Velvet
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753068 Nora

Join the Anime Figure group and share and print anime figures! As well as Updates on what im doing next https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/animefigures
Support me on Patreon! https://www.patreon.com/AnimuAnimu/posts

This print already has all the support material ready to go, DO NOT add SUPPORT MATERIAL.
the support material that i already added to the file has tapered ends and easily breaks off, however be very careful removing, especially around the head. no cutting or gluing necessary.
DO NOT PRINT WITH A RAFT OR SUPPORT MATERIAL

there are TWO stl files included, PRINT THE 3DPrintReady FILE. I included files of the print without supports if you want to add your own supports. note a base is necessary or the model will tip over.

i included my Cura print settings if you were curious, however you should switch to like a .05 mm layer height and a slower print speed to make it look better. if i get around to it, ill print it again at slower speed and post more pictures. i printed mine kind of fast.

i did a bunch of smoothing in Meshmixer, so the stl file is quite big even after being 'reduced' so be patient!

i only had black PLA on hand, im sure a white plastic will make the details show up better, especially in pictures. and wont leave white spots where the support material attached.

Im working on making the whole RWBY gang, but my job is sucking all my time and on top of that meshmixer keeps crashing so be patient!these things a pain to get printable

Note: i reduced the unnecessary triangles after i added the supports, so the file with no supports is much bigger than the other but i didnt feel like going back in and reducing that file lol.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 mm layer height

Infill:

30% this is critical that you make it at least 30 percent

Notes:

I printed this on a monoprice maker select plus (a rebrand of the wanhao, identical printer)
if you want to speed up print time, keep the outer layer slow, so it looks good, but increase the fill print speed.

IMPORTANT: you MUST have AT LEAST a .8mm shell thickness or the supports will fuse with the model!

i included all my Cura print settings in the images
just a pliers and a flush cut to remove any stringing and the break-away supports. be carful removing supports, the model has many detailed and thin features.

this is a scan of an MMD model that posed and edited and made print ready with pmx editor and meshmixer. i also did a lot of smoothing, the scan had sharp polynomials and edges. the sword and Weiss were separate models so aligning the prop was a little tricky. i also quickly made a base for it in SolidWorks. a bunch of detail, like the sword tapering, and her belt/ribbon got lost in the process because it would be near impossible to print.

comments.text: After doing Ruby I wanted to try Weiss next. Cura is super unhappy with the model. Gaps and incomplete surfaces. I tried repairing a bit but gave up. May want to check your model again and give a fresh upload.

comments.text:
so i downloaded the model again and threw it into new ultimaker cura (3.x) and it just doesnt want to slice it for some reason. But when i open it in old cura (IIIP flavor 15.x) which is what i used to print it, it worked just fine. and i printed that exact file myself, and others have 'made' it as well. When i opened the model in meshmixer, it doesnt have any errors, and is all solid. However some of the supports are separate shells, because i left little gaps so that the supports wouldnt adhere fully and could be more easily removed. i think new cura might be freaking out about that, even though i have 'print all at once' turned on, so ill rerender it as a single shell and post it in a bit.
also if that doesnt fix it, it would be helpful if you could email me a picture of what is going on so i can try to fix it, you can reach me at [email protected] thanks

comments.text: Hey Animu,
comments.author: Animu

comments.text: Ok do not stress to much. In a fit of rage I downloaded and configured cura 3.0.4 and sliced. Seemed much better. Currently printing and at the part that always failed. So I will update in a few hours.
comments.author: nightflyertwo

comments.text: Never mind. Still failed. The supports are not staying connected to the base unfortunately. They come off a the slightest touch with my settings.
comments.author: nightflyertwo

comments.text:
alright, i added some more supports to the base of the model to help adhesion. this model was before i switched to thicker supports, so the tips are only 0.25 mm instead of 0.75 like i go with now. i also re-rendered it without reducing triangles, so the file size is big, but it should work now. if you see little gaps in cura while looking at the layers, dont worry about it, the supports will just stretch a bit but wont change the end dimension.
also it is important to note that all the supports should be redundant, so if you see one fail, dont immediately stop the print, see if it will recover, because chances are it will.
the new file is "FixedPrintingIssuesWeiss" make sure to print it at 100% size for best results, and a 0.01mm layer height
let me know if this works now :)
comments.author: nightflyertwo

comments.text: I like how this so 3D printable, compared to some of the stuff on Thingiverse. I tried printing this and one of the supports came off T.T it only printed up to her ankles lol .
comments.author: jiffy3d

comments.text:
are you printing this 100% scale? the supports are only 3mm wide, so printing smaller makes them really fragile. in my newer models im starting to make the supports a bit wider for this purpose.
i tried to make all the supports redundant, so if a few break off, it should still recover, so dont be afraid to run the print and see.
also what you can do to keep the nozzle from breaking off the supports is to enable Z hop, so the head moves up a bit during moments. the third from end picture shows my Cura settings for z hop
if you still cant get it to print i can make a new file with thicker supports, but it may take a few days for me to get to it, im working on a few new models atm. good luck :)
comments.author: jiffy3d

comments.text: Ah it wasn't the actual support structure that broke. I should say the support snapped off from the base . No worries, It's probably some freak mishap. I'm reprinting because it was printing in mid air when the support fell down like a tree :D

comments.text: Needs some adjustment. The 40mm part hits the MP Mini Select's tower when homing. It's a little wider than an actual 40mm fan and doesn't need to be. Also, can't get to the bottom screws on the 30mm fan because the 40mm part is in the way.

comments.text: Thanks for the advice, the bottom screws arent really need for the 30mm and can be filled in with putty. as for the width, I'll look into that, it seems that it works for some and others may need to shave a part of it off or alter the design for a perfect fit.
comments.author: GPSaxophone

comments.text: Maybe offsetting it sightly to the right hand side will help with hitting the tower side? I am looking at doing this mod and I also suspected this may be an issue. Also did you just put the 40mm to the original fan port and then the 30mm fan to the 12v supply after the switch?

Changed the post mounts
I have created 3 versions

  1. Full Post Slide mount - slides on
  2. Full Post Snap mount - tighter snap than the original version - No Glue required
  3. Partial Post Snap mount - tighter snap with less material than the Full Snap version - No Glue Required

Snap mount - place one side on first and then swing the second side around and snap in place.

Added some small permanent supports to make the bridges easier to print with cleaner quality.

All 3 weigh less than 2 grams each

About an hour to print

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1200

Infill:

30%

Notes:

PLA Filament
You will need support for the partial post snap mount.
The other two don't require supports.

description.text: This is the base of a mount that will hold a GPS unit.  It clips into certain brands of mounts that have two rectangular tabs, which fit into the slots on this piece.  I designed the base to have holes for connecting it to various front pieces to fit different GPS units.

Pretty simple. It should just print up. I have not had a chance to test print yet though.
Edit: Printed out quite nicely on the first try. It fits great on the window mount I have. Now just need the other half to hold the GPS.

This is a set of accessories to add to a Nerf Blowgun made out of 1/2" PVC pipe. This includes an ammo holder, front sight, and loops to tie a strap to. SCAD files for this can be found here: https://github.com/creiht/3dstuff/tree/master/nerf

description.text: This bracket was designed to mount a small digital voltmeter on the back of my Powertech MP3800 laboratory power supply. While the power supply does in fact have an analogue voltmeter on the front, I prefer something more precise, with known accuracy. http://teslaandi.wordpress.com/2014/02/02/power-supply-voltmeter-retrofit/

• Purchase one digital voltmeter, as shown in the images (commonly on eBay, referred to as "0.36" LED Display Car Digital Voltmeter"). Ensure that the voltmeter's operating and measurement voltage ratings match the range across which you will be using the power supply.
  • Print one set of brackets as included in the STL file.
  • Assemble as shown.
  • Can be screwed onto the GND and +ve power terminals on the back of the power supply.
  • Connect the black wire to the ground terminal. Connect the red and blue wires to the +ve terminal.

comments.text: Nice one! I just bought the same power supply, so I'm going to make one for the very same reason!

description.text: This is a 5.25" to 1x 3.5" and 1x 2.5" drive bay adapter. It is pictured with my previously designed 3.5" to 2x 2.5" bay adapter mounted in the 3.5" slot. ​Printed in PLA, with 20% infill, weighs only 83 grams. This model can accommodate both 7mm and 9mm drives (7mm pictured)(2.5"). It can also accommodate a 3.5" drive up to 1" in thickness. The mounting screws and hex nuts are standard M3, but any screw should be fine as long as the mounting hex nut has an outer diameter of 6mm or slightly less. While the mounting screw and nut are M3, it is important to note that 2.5" drives utilize M3 screws for mounting. 3.5" drives utilize #6-32 UNC screws. The screws and nuts I used were "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00032Q1J4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1" and "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NBIH92/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1" respectively. Anything with similar dimensions would work just as well. I am in no way trying to promote or advertise these products, but they are the only ones I can guarantee work.​

remixed_from.author: jonaskuehling
remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

title: Greg-Kuehling-Wades Extruder Optimized for E3D V5 3mm

description.text:
This is yet another remix of Greg-Kuehling's famous extruder. I started experimenting with E3D v5 but could not find one with a tight fit. All-metal versions of J-heads and E3Ds are similar, but not the same, which is frustrating because people are making them for one and claiming 100% compatibility with the other. For instance, the two models I found online claimed compatibility with both. However, after mounting my E3D, I found too much lateral movement on the throat, which caused me to create this version. This version eliminates ALL movement between the extruder and hot end.

My version is optimized for E3D v5.

I included two test files (print_test_PLA and print_test_ABS), which have the throat holes for testing purposes. ABS (and exotics like nylon) shrink much more than PLA, so run test prints before printing your extruder accordingly.

**Please make sure to remove all imperfections and plastic debris from the throat holes before mounting your E3D. The throat needs to be completely inside before being secured by the two M3 hex bolts.

*This print will test your printer, so your printer has to be properly calibrated. If not, you may also enlarge objects along the x-y axis before printing (for testing I included the test files to save you the inconvenience of printing a complete extruder).

Highly recommended settings:
50% infill
.2mm layer height

Required hardware:
2x M3 bolts (M3x25)
2x M3 Nuts
2x washers

If you want to test E3D v5, but don't want to print a complete extruder, I have a simple mount right here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2383320

title: Fidget Spinner with Tri and Quad Versions

description.text:
There are plenty of fidget spinners already available on Thingiverse, so why another? Two reasons: first, I enjoy designing things. Second, I wanted to try moving the mass of the weight bearings a bit farther from the center point than it is in most designs. It would seem that having the mass farther out would make it spin longer. My experiments seem to bear this out. I compared a Thingiverse design I printed with my own and got about 30 seconds longer out of mine. With a ceramic 608 bearing in the center, it will spin for about 2:45.

I also wanted to experiment with more weights. I designed the quad spinner to test whether more weight would allow for a longer spin. It seems this is not the case. With the same type of hybrid ceramic 608 bearing in each, the tri design spins about 20-30 seconds longer.

title: Wanhao D7 Z Axis Force Brace
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Depending on which version of the D7 printer you have, this magically (using the force) keeps the z-axis leadscrew from wobbling. This is a solution to using a bearing which under the wrong circumstances can introduce additional problems, or not solve any at all.

For V1.4 (and later) models: Use the Jedi version.
For 1.3 (and earlier models, or if you just hate your printer) Use the Dark Side version.

NOTE: Jar-Jar Binks version in development just to give you something humorous to watch without accomplishing a darn thing.

Satire folks. It fits the D7 like my other mod, but was created for humor purposes only, and I dont testify to the print-ability or function of this mod.

comments.text: The threaded rod wobble has no impact on layer quality. Bearing adjustment along the rail of the Z axis is what you need to do. Holding the end of a wobbly threaded rod may distort the threads and then you WILL have an issue with Z axis control related to the threaded rod.

remixed_from.author: nmsr1196
remixed_from.title: Glowing Apple of Eden with Glowing Base (remix)

description.text:
This is a remix for the Apple of Eden Base. The base now has a snap-fit enclosure. The enclosure is a little smaller than the original one but is a better build thanks to a layer-by-layer tutorial by the Ruiz brothers of Adafruit. The enclosure also was designed to have a hole for a 3mm led and mini SPDT switch. In addition, it has four posts for an Adafruit Trinket (3v or 5v). There are two additional posts in case you want to use, if not, just break them off.
The electronics i used senses the Apple when placed on the base and illuminates it. When the Apple is taken off the base, the base illumination stops. You can view the video from the original and the video below.
All details of the Apple (and its STL(s)) and part numbers ( of suggested electronics) are on the original thing (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1983334). I also attached the short cylindrical post separately which you can glue to the top base. This was done to make printing the base easier. Check out the video below, for the illumination of the base and apple. If you have any questions, please feel free to drop a comment.

remixed_from.author: shorny
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 plus / MK2 - Rasbery pi camera mount

title: Prusa MK2(S) Bed-Mounted Modular Camera System

description.text:
I really liked Shorny's approach to mounting a webcam to the Original Prusa printers but I didn't want to use a Raspberry Pi camera. Additionally, I wanted some flexibility regarding the camera's position (pitch and yaw). As a result, I merged Gyrobot's Ball and Socket design with Shorny's, creating a system that accepts any camera provided you have a socket adapter for it.

For a previous project, I removed my C270 board from its housing and thus needed a replacement housing. I went with Sp0nge's Mini C270 Case. Since it's a basic box, mounting the socket took just five minutes in OpenSCAD, and could be done even faster in MeshLab.

If you'd like the camera bar without the ball mount (for the MK2[S]) on it so the extension arm can be mounted in the center, you can get that here, on Shorny's original thing.

description.text:
Per a request, I came up with to different Oakland Raiders fidget spinners. These use one 608 center bearing and (3) 5/16" nuts for weights. The overall diameter of these are about 3-1/2".

There's a lot of detail in this logo, so I got rid of some of it.

Notes:

If your printer can span over the holes for the nuts, you won't need supports.

These are the various parts of a custom board game pieces based on the wooden Cathedral game. Very basic simple shapes there are many ways you could customize this and add details to (shingles, stonework, gargoyles, windows, ripples in the fountains et.al.) or you could pull other models in for substitute pieces as long as they fit in the spaces, you can prime and paint anyway you want... Printed on an Afinia, 3 layer density, big hole; running ~2.5 hours to 4.5 hours per file depending on print settings. Print time will vary depending on scale and print settings. Be careful printing on perf board as you may tear out the bottom if you don't print enough infill or if you are in a hurry. I aligned objects to fit on an Afinia/Up platform size as well as keeping the print directions and object heights as uniform as possible to make things print a little more efficiently (I guess it's all depending on how you rotate them and how your software slices it up). You may need to slightly modify the two "C" (Castle) shaped buildings, the tolerances are pretty close and depending on ABS expansion your pieces may fit too 'snug'. Print 4x of the game border file to enclose the whole city if you like. I have a Cathedral World set that's showing some signs of wear and tear with two pieces lost that I ended up printing 3d models as substitutes... We also travel set that we had scratch built in wood; I created these so we could print it on the 3D printer using different color ABS as needed or scale them to what ever size one wanted. The church is modified with a hollow cross cut through all four sides of the tower; it can be challenging to clear out the support material but it is possible; If you prefer you can always grab the other cathedral game piece here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:107522 You can tinker with the some of the base models here:
https://tinkercad.com/things/iwYoCVteJrZ
https://tinkercad.com/things/eabMC2YWzE8 More info about the game and the many other variations on BoardGameGeek:
http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/7/cathedral

comments.text: Very cool! Could you please explain which files belong to which player (light or dark)?
comments.author: BrentNewhall

comments.text: Each player gets the same set, one of each large building and 2 of the 1, 2 & 3 square buildings. Except, of course for the cathedral which is unique and should be in a 3rd color (usually gray). Oops! I just remembered the 4 square & non-symmetrical 5 square buildings need to be mirror images in each set - if you turn the the buildings so that the long low parts are horizontal and the tall part of the 5 sq. is on the side away from you the 5 sq with the tall part on the left goes with the 4 sq with the far side tall part on the right. Or go here https://cf.geekdo-images.com/images/pic177878_md.jpg and look at a picture. Also the 3 in a row building is only one per set.
comments.author: BrentNewhall

comments.text: Why recreate the original pieces, more or less, exactly as the appeared? Take some time and come up with some really creative variety. Add parks, villas, and fountains. Even better, model 2 sides for the opponents with different styles to add conflict and tension.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: yes, I definitely agree; I think that sort of question gets asked when people post the standard Staunton chess set models or a simple lasercut go boards to public forums...  I think this set could be used as a starting point for most; I mention customizing and modifying in the first paragraph write up in the thing info. I would think this particular game is perfect for variants, retheming and modification - especially with the ability to customize and print your own miniatures/sculpts to add to the game.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Okay. I recognize that I'm a little late to the party. But I've been playing with some numbers and I've found a way to scale Cathedral up to both a 4 and 6 player variant. All it takes is changing the size of the board and tweaking the shape of the cathedral piece to take up the left over squares.

This thing is a fidget bearing cap with lego studs. It can be installed on any of the bearings. There are four studs that should support a mini-fig or other small lego piece.

Printing will require supports. I printed it with the Lego side up with supports set to "touching build-plate". I have also tried printing with the Lego side down, but clean-up in this orientation was quite tedious.

print_settings.Notes:: Might want to up the infill some of the middle parts that plug into the base are a little fragile when fitting into inserts.

title: LED strip holder for ORION/Rostock Max

description.text:
This is a short extrusion clip used to mount common LED strips to the uprights of the ORION printer. The ORION uses 25.4mm (1in) square extrusions. If the Rostock Max also uses those extrusions, it will also fit the Rostock Max.  
The strips are spaced out forward enough to clear the Cheapskate bearings.

• Print two of these clips
  • Clip to uprights
  • Slide LED strips into the groove from the bottom

comments.text: This thing looks sweet. Where'd ya get the leds? How'd ya hook this up? Thanks!

For example: http://www.amazon.com/Lighting-EVER-Flexible-Daylight-Non-waterproof/dp/B00HSF65MChttp://www.amazon.com/Lighting...
They are 12V. The printers power supply had plenty of spare 12V leads. Hooked up a switch and voila...

print_settings.Notes:: This model is approx 10 cm high, so for six colors, I used ColorPrint by PRUSA3D to apply five filament changes to the file at the following heights (in mm): 16.625, 33.25, 49.875, 66.5, 83.125

description.text:
This is a remake of Pride Flag by MosaicManufacturing (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2382693)

Includes original Blender.blend file and low medium resolution STL.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35 nozzle x .21875 height

Infill:

0%/Hollow

Notes:

Designed in Blender.

I sliced in Slic3r using mostly default Prusa "NO Z HOP"config, modified for .35 nozzle, .21875 layer height, no infill, 3 perimeters, 6 bottom layers, 7 top layers.

(Note that using a "No-Z-Hop" config is critical for the ColorPrint step below.)

This model is approx 10 cm high, so for six colors, I used ColorPrint by PRUSA3D to apply five filament changes to the file at the following heights (in mm): 16.625, 33.25, 49.875, 66.5, 83.125

Made in in Blender, this uses a simple flattened cube for the flag body with two lattice deformations applied.

The first lattice introduces a "wave" in the flag and the second lattice introduces some fattening at the base to make the flag stand up more easily.

Pro tip: if you want an even higher-resolution model, edit the .blend file and turn up the second Subdivision Surface modifier to "2"; the re-export as STL, making sure to multiply scene unit x 1000 for proper real-world unit conversion.

description.text: Modular parts bin. The base model is 5x5x10.5cm with a bin of 4x4x10cm. The 2x1 model is ~10x5x10.5cm with a bin of ~9x4x10cm. All parts are designed based on 5x5cm squares.

First cut 1/8" or 3mm acrylic panels to 40x40mm or 90x40mm (if using the 2x1 bin). Then add a dot or so of hot glue to the bottom edge and slot it in the front of the bin. Lastly use a bit of hot glue to attach the handle to the front of the bin. To make the handle stronger, you can either use hot metal to "weld" it to the bin or use more glue (super glue works).

Using tape and adding a forward facing flap to the back of the bin makes it less likely to fall out.

There's a hole/slot in the back for wall mounting. The size is a bit arbitrary...

Be careful when separating two cases since the slots are a bit fragile.

This entire thing was designed in basically one night because I wanted a flexible place to store and organize all of the random electronic components I had lying around. I'll probably add more size options, and I might come back to redo the connections someday.

This design has been superceded by Ron's Compact Extruder Mark II: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24219 This is Ron's Compact Extruder modified to sit on the Ultimaker's XY carriage. I haven't tested the max speed, but I am able to print at 100mm/s without any trouble. The main advantage is that by removing the Bowden tube from the extruder, there are fewer messy strings after each print. Note: This version of RCX is a mirror image of the original. This allows the lightweight stepper motor to be placed as close to the center of the carriage as possible. Additionally, and as a result, the direction of the extruder stepper does NOT need to be changed in the firmware. Note 2: I've added two OpenSCAD files. The rcx.scad file replaces Ron's rcx.scad. The ultircx.scad is just a wrapper that calls it. (Put all of ron's files in a subfolder called RCX, and ultircx.scad will then know where to find it).

Cut part of the Bowden tube off so that the part remaining inside the XY carriage protrudes on the top by about 5-10mm (total length of the PTFE Bowden tube that remains in the carriage is about 70mm).
Remove two of the long hand-tightened screws that keeps the carriage together. One of them will be removed permanently (it bumps into the idler otherwise). For the one that you remove permanently, reattach the bottom aluminum to the base wood with a 15mm bolt.
Now, attach the Ultimaker Direct Extruder to the top of the carriage, making sure that the PTFE tube protruding from the carriage goes snugly into the hole on the bottom of the UDE. The other two holes on the base of the UDE should line up with the hand-tightening screw holes. Take one of the hand-tightened screws and feed it through the UDE, through the top wooden plate of the carriage, through the bottom wooden plate of the carriage, and then screw it into the aluminum threading at the base. I used pliers to get it tighter than usual.
Use a 20mm bolt to connect the other side of the UDE through the hole where the second hand-tightening screw used to be.
Once attached, a filament of 3mm PLA plastic should feed easily into the PTFE tube directly from the top of the UDE. Woohoo! Direct mounted goodness to enjoy.

Fry's sells batteries in packages of 100. The package they sell them in does not hold the batteries in a reasonable way. The moment you remove the 1st battery, the rest rearrange themselves into a confused jumble.
I looked at the other battery dispensers and did not find any that would hold 100 batteries. Also most of them held the batteries in a single file line. I wanted a holder where I could dump batteries into it a handful at a time.
This dispenser works without jamming, but it does have some drawbacks. It is too tall, and uses too much plastic. I believe that there is a lot of room for improvement, but as is, it is sufficient for my needs.
The dispenser could probably be made a lot shorter if the steep funnel was set at an angle, but that would require some experiments to see how sharp a corner could be handled at the junction to the shallow funnel so that it still works without jamming.

This is built in two or three pieces, depending on what fits on your build plate.
You will need to edit parameters in the BatteryDispenerParameters.scad file.
You will need to generate the BatteryDispensor.scad file twice, once with the Mirror variable set to 1, and once with the Mirror variable set to -1. This will generate the two halves of the base.
If what fits on your build plate has too small a hopper, you will need to generate the Hopper Extension. With HopperWidth set to 10 and BaseHopperHeight set to 1 (the minimum), the base holds about 50 batteries. At BaseHopperHeight set to 6, it holds 100.
