title: Otto DIY+ Arduino Bluetooth robot easy to 3Dprint

description.text:
Who is Otto DIY+ (PLUS)?

Otto DIY+ is the improved and advanced version of original #OttoDIY, have the same base features DIY robot + Bluetooth control and programming + metal gear servo motors MG90S + optional rechargeable + changing modes by touch sensors + sound sensor + your unlimited imagination

Otto DIY+ is a forever open for improvements!, developed by a broad international and diverse community of Otto builders,

buy our full kits!

Visit http://www.ottodiy.com/

List of parts:

  1. Arduino Nano;
  2. Arduino Nano Shield I/O Extension Board Expansion XD-212
  3. Mini usb cable.
  4. HC-SR04 Ultrasound sensor.
  5. Mini servo MG90 9g x4 (each one should come with 2 pointed screws and one small screw also arm keys to attach legs and feet).
  6. passive Buzzer 12mm 5V
  7. Female to Female breadboard connectors cable 10cm x24.
  8. 4 AA Battery case
  9. 1.5V AA batteries x4.
  10. Phillips screwdriver (important magnetized)
  11. micro Switch 8x8mm
  12. Touch sensors x3
  13. Sound sensor
  14. Bluetooth module HC-05 or HC06 or BLE

And then you only need to 3D print 6 parts in total:

  1. 3D printed head.
  2. 3D printed body.
  3. 3D printed leg x2.
  4. 3D printed right foot.
  5. 3D printed left foot.

How to build your own Otto?

Recommended to first check all documentation for Otto DIY if you are a beginner and then you can try to play with more advanced features with Otto DIY+

use the Mini USB cable to power your circuit from your computer or a USB socket.

Codes, Bluetooth & APP

Codes for Bluetooth already here: https://github.com/OttoDIY/PLUS
The APP is ready!
get the .apk here https://github.com/OttoDIY/PLUS/tree/master/APP
and you can make your own using our app inventor template

You can use MBlock for simple an easy graphical programming

Otto builder group

So for any issue or question please follow this topic
https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/ottodiy/topic:16553

Thanks to Brandon Bowles we have a Thingiverse customizer, so you can change easily the size and parameters as you desire
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2457865
NGSS CCSS
open source STEAM

Truly open source nature of Otto allows open STEAM education, we collect feedback from different workshops and schools around the world that are already using Otto DIY in their classroom and depending of the openness of this educational places we organize the lesson material and share as well, some people are teaching electronics connections with Fritzing and the physics behind, other code with MBlock, Scratch, Arduino then collaborative coding with Github, other to create open source APPs in app inventor, other how to customize with arts & crafts, other how to design 3d models with accessories for Otto using openSCAD or TinkerCAD or Fusion 360. 
If you are interested to give feedback around this please message me ;)

Build your Own Otto But…Who is Otto? Otto is an interactive robot that anyone can make!
What can Otto do? Otto walks, dances, makes sounds and avoids obstacles
Why Is Otto special? Otto is completely open source, 3D printable, and Arduino compatible This is the opportunity to build and have your first robot.
First there will be a little introduction about Otto and the team behind, Second you will receive one Otto DIY kit including all tools you need to make this biped robot. And lastly you will follow the assembly instructions and you would be able to finish your new Otto robot and play. Includes one Otto DIY kit and all the tools to build it in 2-3 hours. No need technical knowledge, perfect for beginners and easy hackable for experts. Due small screws the workshops is recommend for 7+ years old, unless the children are accompanied by parents. Code your own Otto Ok so was fun to build now lets get into Otto's brain. By following the instructions will start to program your own robot by just modifying few lines of code, the simplicity of the function will help to easily jump into coding. Create your own APP We can play and control Otto from cellphone using Bluetooth yes but... that is pretty much a remote control, what else can we do? By using APP inventor students can create their own apps and create new functions that are not only meant to "move the robot" Design your own robot Using TinkerCAD or Autodesk Fusion 360 or OpenSCAD (for more advance students) will be able to modify the source files or even recreate them to make you own robot and applied all the knowledge from the previous lessons. Customize, modify, remix and recreate your own Otto. then share to the world!

Workshops Bring all list of electronic parts mentioned before and all 3d components of Otto printed. Take some extras of each parts specially servos they break easily. Is good to have some extra AA batteries or rechargeable (if is the case) and a soldering iron in case of accidents and further making. Print the instruction manual in A6 format and have them organize and ready for the class.

• ideation
  • creativity
  • reasoning
  • problem solving
  • sequential thinking
  • mechanic
  • coding
  • motor capacity
  • programming
2 hours for build your own Otto
Test your own Otto show what you learned free assessment to show your creativity

author: thewerefox

description.text:
Hello Dear all Flux Delta 3D Printer User

I design this for reducing the vibration of the Flux Delta 3D Printer. It would increase the accuracy especially in Low quality mode.
I attach the holder hook(file B&C) with 3M Command Damage Free Strips and It's easy to remove if you don't wanna use the holder anymore.
Print the file A(Holder body) and file B & C(Holder Hook) first with low quality mode. then use the holder to fix Flux Delta. Then Printer the File D(Holder Cover) and File E with Low quality mode. you will find out the accuracy is much better after you use the Holder to fix 3D printer. Enjoy your printing and have fun.

What is it?

This is a thing for holding and turning 2020 (20x20mm) and 3030 (30x30mm) aluminium extrusions for spray painting. I used a few of these to help paint the frame for a HyperCube Evolution 3D printer.

It works with Motedis 3030 and 2020 Bosch-type (B) extrusions, and the centre hole fits a wire coat hanger with the plastic stripped off.

My painting steps were: rough up with 180 grit sanding pad, clean with tack cloth and solvent, etch primer (2 coats), paint (3 coats) and clear coat (2 coats). Appropriate safety equipment (respirator, gloves etc.) should be used especially with the primer.

Conclusions

After painting the frame for a HyperCube Evolution was it worth it?

Pros

  • Black anodised extrusions aren't universally available and the painted extrusions look good (in my opinion of course)

Cons

  • Cost (primer, paint, more paint, clear coat, respirator etc - it adds up)
  • The time and effort involved were not inconsiderable plus you're dealing with some fairly unpleasant fumes
  • It makes assembly more challenging because parts bind or stick rather than slide
  • The paint will almost-inevitably get damaged during assembly

I made an extruder according to Neo_Usagi's design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:494430/. But I think the force of extruder is too small. So I put the right arm offset 1mm inside, so that the pressure generated by gear becomes greater.

title: Tusken Raider Cycler Rifle (Basic from SWToR)

description.text:
The Tusken Cycler was the standard projectile weapon used by the Tusken Raiders of Tatooine in ranged combat. The cycler was an older design of rifle and fit into the slugthrower class, firing solid shots enveloped in energy, not blaster bolts. The weapon emitted a unique sound when fired, rather like a cross between a blaster and a musket.
http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Tusken_Cycler_rifle

Notes:

print_settings.Notes:: http://www.progressth.org/2017/07/diy-friction-welding-warped-3d-prints.html

description.text:
This is a project in progress. Read more here: http://www.progressth.org/p/grow-box.html

The 3D printed parts included here are to mount a planter above a 350mm tall, 220mm diameter glass container. A small water pump circulates water from the container below, to a perlite filled, inverted 6 liter water bottle above. Holes have been drilled into the water bottle's cap for drainage back into the glass container. The bottom section of the bottle has been cut off and the remaining cross section is used as a mount for the inverted bottle top.

There is a rectangular hole in the top cover that will be used for ports or as an electronics bay for automation.

The SketchUp files has been included so that users can adjust the design to suit glass containers and pot sizes they have on hand.

The pieces are printed in halves and friction welded together. The casing is particularly tall and warping required a piece of filament to be placed in the gap to bridge it when welding. For an overview of friction welding see here: http://hackaday.com/2014/12/30/3d-printing-technique-friction-welding/

(NOTE: if the water bottle is not inverted, and holes drilled into the bottom of the bottle instead, water tends to cling to the surface and travel toward the edges and onto the 3D printed platform. While the design of this system reduces spill hazards, because of questions regarding the food-safety qualities of 3D printed plastic, it is designed so no water ever comes in contact with any 3D printed parts.)

Printer:

ExtraBot 3020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

40% or more.

Notes:

Requires a lot of friction welding, including filling in gaps in the case halves with lengths of 3D printing filament. For more information on friction welding, see here: http://hackaday.com/2014/12/30/3d-printing-technique-friction-welding/

If your case sides come out warped, you can still friction weld it together. Simply use a length of filament to fill the gap and weld over it. Read more here: http://www.progressth.org/2017/07/diy-friction-welding-warped-3d-prints.html

title: After Bekah Carran's Dawn In The New Age (pendant)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This object has been developed as part of the art project "Whisper Down The Lane", currently being developed by Bronwyn Holloway-Smith in conjunction with the exhibition The Obstinate Object: Contemporary New Zealand Sculpture at City Gallery Wellington, New Zealand (24 February â€“ 10 June 2012). During the exhibition digital 3D models will be made of selected works in The Obstinate Object in collaboration with designers Ant Pelosi and Nick Graham. The files for these models will be released for free download on Thingiverse under a Creative Commons BY-SA-NC License. Each physical work in this series is also available for purchase through a manufacture-on-demand system. The models are being produced in New Zealand using the Open Source RepRap 3D printer (with Vik Olliver). Order editions on the project webpage: http://bronwyn.co.nz/projects/whisper-down-the-lane The project will start with one work and will then gradually grow over the course of the exhibition as new works are completed and released. To receive notifications of new releases follow @hollowaysmith on Twitter, or join the mailing list at http://bronwyn.co.nz/contact/

Slice the file and print each "bead" separately. Make sure there are holes to thread them together.
The base may need to be printed with support material and/or in two pieces that are then glued together (sliced horizontally).
For the base, use a piece of aluminium tube, mark it in place and cut to size with a little circular saw dremmel attachment. File off the burred edges, fit it (pushing it in with a chopstick to not damage the thin tube), file a bit more, and then use a tapered punch to spread the two ends so it doesn't come out easily. You may need to soften the plastic to make sure the edges are flush and brush the wire inside the tube to remove the worst of the marks made by the punch.
The wire is coated stainless shark trace, and aluminium 1.5mm electricians "bootlace ferrule" was used for the crimped join.

This is a redesigned version of my custom effector plate for the Micromake C1. This version is designed to fit onto a MGN9H carriage for a MGN9 linear rail and has mounting options for a 5015 radial fan (highly recommended!). title: Axel's Tri Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another fidget spinner. This one is designed for 608 bearings to be used both in the centre and also as weights. As with all spinners, use ceramic bearings for the best spin time. The spinner is slightly asymmetric making it easier to start it. It also uses interlocking centre caps for assembly without glue. The caps will never fall out. the hole dimensions are exactly correct, so depending on how your printer is calibrated, the press fit will be very tight.

Update 2017-07-21
I added an outer cap if you want to cover the outer ball bearings. I have also changed the design of the centre cap slightly and added a new variant of the centre cap with an indentation making it easier to grip. The centre cap with indentation is also harder to print, use supports and try to print it up side down.

author: Axbri

description.text: My son wanted a Celtic knot bracelet. This library was used to create my first attempt. The library contains a couple of examples at the top with some example patterns. The latest version will be on github at https://github.com/beanz/celtic-knot-scad The API is still work-in-progress so expect changes. Feedback would be much appreciated so that the API can be firmed up sooner rather than later. For the next iteration of the bracelet I'm planning to create a celtic knot font of the tile alphabet for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193 so then it should be possible to "draw" knots on cylinders and spheres too. UPDATE 2014/02/02: Removed use of children() which isn't supported on older versions of openscad.

title: Small enclosure for GPS module, LED and button
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A small enclosure that fits a GPS module, a 6x6 mm button, and a 5 mm LED. The top part snaps in place. I designed it for my RC glider, but I think it would be perfect on any airplane, drone, quadcopter or DIY robot.

description.text:
I got this Digital microscope from Banggood and fancied a proper stand for it. As it comes with a rubbish sticky suction cup. Grabbed the nicest looking Microscope model from Thingiverse and had a little play.

https://www.banggood.com/Mustool-G600-Digital-Portable-1-600X-3_6MP-Microscope-Continuous-Magnifier-with-4_3inch-HD-OLED-Display-p-1119592.html?rmmds=search

I extended the base (in not a very attractive fashion :P) to accommodate the added swing out of the microscope. Extended the inspection plate (and got shot of the light hole).

Modified the rack to print as one piece with an adapter to fit the microscope mount (now a slightly difficult part to print as most of it required support).

Got rid of the logo in the adjuster handles so as to save print time.

The central hub has had most of its clearances tightened up for a little more friction, I also increased the amount of mesh between the rack and pinion. It runs smoothly and holds itself up nicely.

The base I printed with no bottom layers, full hexagonal infill at 20%. This is so I can use my old sand filling technique. As the part is slab sided, ill add weight to it by filling the part with sand from the bottom, then sealing it all in with some resin, I use XTC3D from smooth on.

The rest is printed at 35% infill, 2 walls, 3 bottom layers, 4 top layers, 0.15mm layer thickness.

All parts were printed on my Ultimaker 2+ in colorfabb PLA/PHA. The three print runs took about 30 hours in all and roughly 400g of material.

I threw up the sketchup file, Not very organised, only grouped parts with no layers, but theres not much to it really :P.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20-35%

Notes:

I used colorfabb PLA/PHA

Sliced on Simplify 3D

Nozzle temp
Layer 1 230 Deg. C
Layer 2 225 Deg. C

Bed temp
Layer 1 60 Deg. C
Layer 2 50 Deg. C

Fan speed
Layer 1 0%
Layer 2 50%
Layer 3 100%

0.4mm Nozzle

First layer height 130%
First layer Speed 30%

No raft, Skirt used

Full Hexagonal infill

51.7 mm/s base speed

description.text:
Just for all of you who insist the Earth is flat, here is a Flat Earth Globe. Now you can show your friends the living proof, and astound them with you knowledge of astronomy.

The image is about 115mm diameter (4-1/2 inches)

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The gimbal prints in one. I got the best result on the base with more top and side layers and 0.2mm. YMMV.

Adding the image

The image has an extra wide green outer border to make cutting to size a little less demanding. It should be printed at 100%. I used photo paper and Photoshop. A lot of lesser apps seem to want to size to fit the paper. You could also print onto self adhesive label stock.

I used double side adhesive sheet that I happened to have.

Design

Modeled in Fusion 360. The image was taken from https://makingmaps.net/2007/09/19/making-flat-earth-globes/ where there's an inviation to download the image. I added the wider green border using CorelDRAW.
The zip file contains the image as well as the stl files

hello, how long we need for carbon tube 6mm, 8mm, 10mm please ?
thanks
comments.author: spawn50260

comments.text:
Hi it all depends on your draw length but I used the following for a 30'' draw length @ 30 lb draw weight:
2 x 10mm x 260mm L for the band stop (1 each side)
4 x 8mm x 145mm L for the stabilizers (2 each side)
2 x 8mm x 20mm L for the top stabilizer rollers (1 each side)
6 x 6mm x 200mm L for the limbs (3 each side)
2 x 5mm x 12mm L brass threaded inserts for the stabilizers(NOTE! NOT LIMB STABILIZERS)
14 x M5 bolts (variable lengths)
6 x M5 nyloc nuts
2 x M3 x 35mm L (+ 4 zip ties) for attaching the 3mm band tubes
For the arm rest it has to be solid round bar 10mm OD
NOTE!: Chamfer all the holes so as to make tube insertion easier, You can also use Aluminum, Steel or brass tubes instead of the carbon tubes but the carbon looks Bad A$$ lol ;)

author: Meschaninov

description.text:
The Prusa i3 MK2S is a great printer especially for the hobbyist or light industrial desktop user. That having been said it is a raw printer without a lot of accessories that would make it a great printer. The is the Third in a series of accessories that I designed for the i3. The others are:

  • Enclosure
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2396990
  • HEPA Air Scrubber
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2394452
  • OctoPrint Print Server
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2401423

The filament holder supplied with the i3 is mounted to the top printer structure and will not fit into the enclosure. Other popular spool holders likewise will not fit into the enclosure and operate satisfactorily.

This Filament Spool Holder is designed to sit on the top of the enclosure immediately above the print head path and to unspool filament through a Filament Guide to the print head.

The design incorporates large, low cost, ball bearings as resting places for the standard width 67mm spools from manufacturers such as Inland, Hatchbox, and others. Other widths can be accommodated by removing one or both sides from the base and manually positioning them on the enclosure surface as required.

The use of the large ball bearings provides a near friction free unspooling mechanism that minimizes the filament drag on the print head.

Print Sides and Base

The bearing mounts are purposely designed to be an interference fit with the bearings themselves. This eliminates the need for fasteners of an kind.

Print 4 sides and 1 base or print the assembly STL. The later contains all the needed parts in one file.

Assemble Sides

Place two Sides on a flat surface and gently tap two bearing on each side. The Inter-Race should be positioned tightly against the Outer Boss. See picture below. Make sure the outer bearing (rotating part) does not touch the sides at any point.

Place the remaining Sides over the bearings assembled above and gently tap those sides opposite the bearings with a wood mallet or equivalent until the top side is fully engaged with each bearing. Ensure the Inter-Race is tight against he Outer Boss.

Make sure the bearings turn freely.

Assemble Sides with Base

Place each side in the slots in the Base.

Center the sides on the base. Failure to do so will result in the spool "running" to one side during operation. In extreme cases the spool could fail to rotate or come off the Spool Holder all together.

Bill of Materials
  • 4 ea 35x17x10 Ball Bearings
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FOIEI9G
  • 4ea Sides (3D Printed)
  • 1ea Base (3D Printed)

SN08-N / SN04-N sensor mount for central installation infront of a 40mm heatsink fan.

author: Madmax64

title: Nerf Stryfe Motor Cover with Rail
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original one didn't leave a means of actually attaching it to the Stryfe and gluing didn't work or look good. It didn't work because of all the angles involved... You can now bolt it to the Stryfe using 20mm M3 countersunk screws with nuts... line it up to where it needs to be then just drill trough the holes in this to make the holes in the stryfes shell... I obviously added a picatinny rail to cover the front "Gap" ...

I hope you like my "Pacman" num numm nummm

https://youtu.be/VaLUBIIwKmg
https://youtu.be/IG-tF6vIC3o

comments.text: Think you could upload a version without the rail?
comments.author: Xellos

comments.text: Nice! Yeah, this was one of my earliest designs, so it is flawed in many areas of the design. That Stryfe looks awesome, but I probably would not go out in public with it.
comments.author: Ryan_Taki

comments.text: Yeah  i agree with both of those statements.. thanks for the original part
comments.author: Ryan_Taki

comments.text: Out of curiosity, what motors are you running and what flywheels/flywheel cage is installed?
comments.author: Ultrasonic2

comments.text:
I think it they are these motors .. 180ph-3831/47
http://www.ebay.com/itm/1pcs-3-7V-4-2V-6V-7-2V-HM-180-Motor-DC-high-speed-motor-Model-Belt-cooling-holes-/132212152628?hash=item1ec8755934
comments.author: Ryan_Taki

comments.text: when it comes to motors the higher the RMP/Volt the higher the power the motor is at ANY given VOLTAGE
comments.author: Ultrasonic2

comments.text:
We want high Power to spin up fast but ultimately DONT want the Crazy RPM associated
with HIGH RPM/Volt as that just turns the stryfe into a wood chipper..... SO give it High RPM/Volt motors ( high power ) and just give it a burst of pull power to get them up to your desired rpm as fast as possible. Once there then just PWM them (Reduce power to the motors) to keep them at your target RPM
comments.author: Ultrasonic2

comments.text: Correct me if I am wrong, but from what I understand, you run the motors at 12.6 volts at start up to get a faster rev time, then reduce it down to 7.4 volts for optimal performance
comments.author: Ultrasonic2

comments.text: Well i was meant to give it full power and then PWM them down BUT that never happened cos i ran out of time... The motors died / sound so bad because the bushings have gone. Had they had Ball bearings Or were spun at a more realistic RPM they would have lasted better/ been fine.
comments.author: Ryan_Taki

comments.text:
For a given input Voltage as RPM increases Torque reduces..
You can counter this by increasing the voltage as RPM increases to keep the torque constant. ( overly simplified ) ... Btu this is how stepper motors work.. (Well current limited ones )
comments.author: Ultrasonic2

comments.text: that is the coolest stryfe i have ever seen.
comments.author: Abusive

comments.text: Thanks i think it looks awesome too. Better than i was expecting.. If you want you can print your own... im updating all the files and uploading them over the next week or so.. i will then make a few videos on you tube about how to make it
comments.author: Abusive

title: Nerf Stryfe AR15 / M4 Carbine Extendable Stock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are the files for the updated Stryfe stock (Version 3) i made version 2. I have changed everything but the major improvements are improved stock sliding mechanism. I Also added the "Nut" thing at the base of "AR15-reciver_extension" to make it look better and to make it a bit longer (10mm). Also i have changed the stock to Stryfe mounting system to be a "crush" type.

AR15-reciver_extension.STL
The crush slot for the mounting bolt has a 45 degree taper so you can print this vertically and enable supports from the base and as longer as your angle is greater than 45 then it wont support in that gap which could be hard to get out if it did print in there. The bolt is a
M4 45mm with nut.

After printing the above print
Normal_Size_Test.STL This is a profile of the stock you can make this first to see if it fits AR15-reciver_extension.STL... if not print Normal_Size_Test_025_over_size.STL and try that one...

After that print the right size Stock
AR15-main_stock.STL/AR15-main_stock_025oversize.STL
I have made too version because everyone hates making things that don't fit. So now you have two options.. FYI i printed AR15-main_stock.STL

You can then print the latch AR15-stock_latch.STL

If you want you can print AR15-stock_swivel.STL and AR15-stock_swivel_screw.STL for some more eye candy. However i haven't printed these yet and it's unlikely they will be able to support any weight.. Im assuming you'll glue the screw in.

The Stock to receiver still needs more fin tuning in bolt length and Spring.
I believe i used a M4 "Flat" head screw driver screw that was about 35mm long you then print MD_m4_pin_lock.STL and slide it over the bolt. I was not sure what spring would be gets so i bought a range of them but i still feel they are TO weak. I used a 50mm "wire 0.4mm outer diameter 7mm Stainless Steel Small spot compression" i would go for some thing shorter but with a significant increase in wire diameter next time.. ID can be 4mm and OD can be 8mm, well that is the space provided in not suggesting a spring of that dimensions. I would like to hear back form the community on a better spring weight and bolt length. The nut NEEDS to be a M4 LOCK NUT.. not what i used in my pic/video

m4 Lock Nut
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/UjUfEee

The Licence you agree to when downloading this thing prevents you from making a profit from MY thing. This means you CAN NOT sell this or any of my other things on places like Ebay, Facebook, Forums or Etsy. You also may Not sell My parts as Part of a complete blaster. I don't profit from putting this thing us as a Free download and therefore no one else should too.

Based on this by "Les.T." But SOOO much has been changed.
https://grabcad.com/library/assembled-m4--1

Printed on Tronxy X3A 3D Printer

Update 03/Sep/2017
Uploaded a 2 part receiver tube for people who's printers can't print so high to print the original one... It's meant glued together (which is what was requested)

https://youtu.be/VaLUBIIwKmg
https://youtu.be/IG-tF6vIC3o

remixed_from.author: revolucion3D
remixed_from.title: I3 CORDOBESA Full Steel  1/8" LASERCUT with Bowden extruder

description.text:
P3STeel mejorada, totalmente realizada en metal.
Se ha eliminado las bridas.
Se simplifica el sistema de amarre de la correa al carro X, eliminando el sistema de prisionero que era complicado de montar.
Se adapta el sistema de varilla roscada a varilla trapezoidal.
Se ha cambiado y mejorado los sistemas de arrastre, para que no rocen las correas, ni se tensen excesivamente por falta de paralelismo de los dos lados de la correa.
En este caso hay algunos tornillos que roscan directamente sobre la chapa cortada, por lo que hay que roscar un par de agujeros.
Igualmente hay un par de avellanados, para dejar, en algunos casos los tornillos al ras de la chapa.
Son operaciones básicas fáciles de realizar y que no exigen una gran destreza ni grandes medios técnicos.
Se mejorará el carro, para que pueda soportar tanto doble extrusor ED3 V6 como extrusores simpes y dobles compactos.
Se añadirá un soporte en el carro para llevar una tarjeta de conexionado rápido que permita el cambio rápido de extrusor compacto.
Se modificará la estructura para soportar dos estrusores para Bowden, además de poder usarlos compactos.
Se incluirá guiado del hilo para el caso de usar extrusor compacto y el portarrollos superior.
Se crearán soportes para los rollos cuando se use Bowden.
Se reformará el sistema de sujección de los rodamientos de cama para evitar que se bloqueen los rodamientos por demasiado apriete en caso de usar rodamientos igus.
..... y lo que vaya surgiendo.

author: tmag432

description.text:
These are some cavern tiles and tombstones I modified for different sizes to be used as the base for grass tiles. (Just mix 50% PVA/white glue and water, brush on, and then cover in grass flock. You can make flock very easily from sawdust mixed with very cheap paint from any big box hardware store.)

After the grass is dry (or before it would work as well), paint up the tombstones and glue them on. I left the tombstones separate because randomizing where you place them makes for a more versatile graveyard.

I'm putting them up as a pack to make it very easy for people to make a graveyard set for RPGs.

author: Mikulas

print_settings.Notes:: I know I say "make sure you have a level bed, kids!" And that's important, for sure. But if you're using a glass bed, or something else that can "wiggle" around, make absolutely certain that it's locked in and not wiggling.  When I printed this for my mom, the bed had a little wiggle-room, so some of the layers were slightly offset.  She said she was cool with it, and I sent it to her as-is.  But if you want it to look like a box, and not all weird and shaggy, you should level your bed, and make sure your bed is not moving around in the X and Y! (Unless that's what it's designed to you, in which case, you have a weird bed!)

title: Precision Tool Desk Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's one of the ten commandments! "Honour thy father and thy mother."

I grabbed a more British version of that bible quote because I think the thees and thys are a little cooler, plus, you get honor with a "u!"

Why did I quote the bible today, when I'm usually quoting my favorite video game? "We don't understand! You're totally not religious!" I know, but I don't believe any of Stephen King's books but I quote them too. The bible is a fantastic work of fiction - of biblical proportions - and it's got some good stuff in it. But why today?

Okay, so my mom is a jeweler, and she has been for a very long time. I know when my dad was a jeweler, his desk was always a mess. Now my mom...much less of a mess. But how do you organize all these little tools? Buy a little red tool box? Probably not. These are precision tools, very expensive. They are designed to work on watches, and other jewelry, and have very specific purposes.

So when I told my mom I could 3D design and print stuff, she asked for a desk organizer. Wow! She was very specific: she showed me this small brick of foam she'd been using to safely store her bench knives, and so that's where I started.

The two slits on the left-hand side work great for holding knives - long or short. We gave a symmetrical distance on the top and bottom, and the "slit" goes almost all the way through, leaving you plenty of room for longer knives.

I added the five smaller holes in the top, in a "5 dice" pattern, and when she saw the smaller holes rendered on the box, she asked if I could add another section for larger tools. She was very specific! Three larger holes on the right-hand side, and I arranged them in an "arrow" shape pointing to the right.

These holes and arrangements, as you can see, work perfectly for my mom's bench tools. The holes go very deep into the block - leaving a few millimeters to keep things manifold and happy.

You can print this in any color you'd like. I just happened to have PLA white on the printer, but I imagine, this would look cooler in a darker color like charcoal (why is that so hard to spell sometimes? It's just "char" and "coal" put together!) or black. The main thing is, this is a safe place to put a couple of knives (as long as they fit in the slits), and a bunch of tools (as long as they fit in the holes).

If you'd like a custom version, I just need to know how many holes, what diameter and depth, and what arrangement. If you can download this, print it, and do an "I Made One" on Thingiverse, we can then communicate through words and pictures much more effectively. If you want your name on the final custom piece, I can totally do that.

You may be into 3D design, and that's cool too. It's a brick of plastic with holes in it. Not really fancy or spectacular. If you do make one, please share! If you remix this, again, please share, because it's always nice to see your babies grow up!

Sorry this wasn't so funny today. I promise, I'll be back tomorrow with a Thing that will put a smile on your face!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I know I say "make sure you have a level bed, kids!" And that's important, for sure. But if you're using a glass bed, or something else that can "wiggle" around, make absolutely certain that it's locked in and not wiggling. When I printed this for my mom, the bed had a little wiggle-room, so some of the layers were slightly offset. She said she was cool with it, and I sent it to her as-is. But if you want it to look like a box, and not all weird and shaggy, you should level your bed, and make sure your bed is not moving around in the X and Y! (Unless that's what it's designed to you, in which case, you have a weird bed!)

How to Assemble

Ha! Tricked you. No assembly required!

If you want to clean this up, it would be trivial to sand the flat surfaces so the layer lines are cleaner. You could prime and paint it, sand it a little more...I dunno. It's a functional desk tool, so go crazy with it if you want to, but I think it'll look super pretty on a desk.

It's a block of plastic, designed to keep you organized and safe.

Maybe, some day, I'll make a piece of art that also lets you store your small desk implements?

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

Fusion 360 is my friend. It lets me design awesome 3D objects, and then process them over in Simplify 3D for printing. Super nice!

This is literally a box of plastic: cubic, rectangular, squared-off. Sure, there are fillets, because I like rounded corners, and the holes and slits are your basic holes and slits.
